The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of current debate. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators, which is the mathematical foundation of quantum mechanics. Our characterization is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. Our results provide a foundation for a reconstruction program for quantum mechanics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic data for two myxozoan species, and we compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the parasitic lifestyle. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings may help to design antiviral strategies against SARS-CoV-2 and other viruses that use similar mechanisms to evade the host immune system. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries, leading to a higher probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in savanna ecosystems. However, the extent to which species partition food resources at the level of individual species is unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivore species in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, species differed in their diet composition, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that large herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the need for more comprehensive species-level diet analyses in future studies of large herbivore diets and their effects on biodiversity.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. The majority of businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly due to the size-selective sinks of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud. However, the formation of the solar system is still a matter of debate. In this study, we determined the age of presolar silicon carbide grains, which are thought to have condensed in the outer layers of the envelopes of asymptotic giant branch stars.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother during pregnancy is a key factor in the evolution of sociality. In this study, we show that the evolution of sociality is associated with an increase in the amount of energy available to the mother. This increase is associated with an increase in the number of offspring produced, without compromising the size of the offspring. This increase in reproductive output is associated with the evolution of allonursing, a form of allomaternal care that has been shown to be associated with the evolution of sociality in humans and other mammals. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work also highlights the importance of the mother in the evolution of sociality. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA pathology. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to slow down the progression of MSA. This work opens the door to a clinical development of this drug in MSA patients. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels. It is a highly specialized cell layer that controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. It also controls the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a network of cells that is connected to the outside world by a variety of receptors. It is important to understand the structure of this network and how it works. Here, we show that the network is organized in a way that is effective for both local and global communication.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals and auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The COVIDcast API is a resource that can be used to track the pandemic, to augment traditional public health reporting, and to empower research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are thus the focus of intense research. In this study, we have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the collapse of the selectivity filter can lead to the structural transition from C-type inactivation to closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also opens the door to the development of new pharmacological tools for the study of these important ion channels. (Show more)

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is influenced by the host animal and the plant diet. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of herbivores is not fully understood, but it is thought to be important in the regulation of the host immune system. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi in the gut of herbivores produce natural products that could be important in the regulation of the microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings indicate that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work highlights the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and points to a potential role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a key mechanism in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. These findings have implications for understanding the role of anxiety in social behavior and for the development of new therapeutic approaches for social disorders. (Show more)

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the available materials and manufacturing processes. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the synthesis of multiple materials into composite structures, which are then assembled into architectures with complex responses. The synthesized structures are irregular in shape and material distribution, yet they can precisely achieve the target responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with highly complex and navigable responses. The proposed synthesis and assembly strategy can be utilized to design and manufacture mechanical devices with specific responses for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in vertebrates. In humans, the hemoglobin system is regulated by a complex network of factors, including the let-7 microRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in this network. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal period and is down-regulated in the adult period. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key player in the regulation of the hemoglobin system in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the long-term use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Our study shows that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings may help to develop new strategies for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but that the policy failed to reverse the decline of older forest bird populations. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral bird populations, and the creation of early-seral ecosystems may impede the development of older forest structure. These findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the development of older forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. To combat this problem, we developed a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We tested all compounds for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our study demonstrates the potential of computational design of antibiotics. (Show more)

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and can be used in a wide range of problems. The proposed architecture is a simple and effective way to reduce the number of parameters required to achieve accurate results in image processing.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of this exposure on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event that is thought to have been triggered by a bolide impact. However, the exact nature of the impactor is still debated. In this study, we show that the osmium isotope composition of the Younger Dryas ejecta is consistent with a terrestrial source. This suggests that the impactor was a terrestrial object and that the bolide impact was the main cause of the Younger Dryas cooling.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the function of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is dependent on the developmental stage at which it is deleted.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 1,460 species to trace the evolution of beetles and to identify the genes that enabled the evolution of their unique feeding habits. We found that the evolution of plant-feeding habits was driven by the acquisition of genes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls. These genes were acquired multiple times, and the evolution of specialized feeding habits was accompanied by a diversification of beetles. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and the adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of beetles and other insects. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that, contrary to previous research, population size does not enhance CCE. Instead, we found that the size of the population may have overwhelmed the working memory of the participants, and that it was only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the design of future experiments and the interpretation of past research. They also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to the innovation and adaptation of artifacts.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a lipid-binding protein that is highly expressed in the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies suggest that APOE may be a key player in AD pathophysiology.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely to occur than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is likely to be composed of the bcc phase, which is a rare phase in nature. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. This study provides evidence that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex cognitive skill we have. In this work, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can predict the contents of the human science literature on language processing. This suggests that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are tuned to the most important aspects of language processing. We also find that the predictive model architecture contributes to the strength of the neural fit. These results provide computational evidence for the importance of predictive processing in language comprehension.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still an open problem to develop a rigorous mathematical foundation for DL. In this paper, we show that the success of DL is due to the existence of a special class of stable neural networks (NNs). We also develop a theory of stability for NNs, which is a fundamental problem in machine learning. Our results provide a mathematical justification for the success of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific controversy. The pandemic is a scientific controversy because it is a matter of opinion whether the pandemic is caused by a virus or by the human response to it. This paper is about the latter cause of the former. It is about the scientific controversy over the role of psychology in the pandemic.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of it has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the causative agent of Hansen's disease, M. leprae. We found that the two pathogens are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation, and that the loss of genes in M. lepromatosis may be related to its ability to infect the nervous system. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of the leprosy disease complex and the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement is a key question in quantum information theory and quantum chaos. It is also of fundamental importance in the study of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we provide a general framework for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid and large-scale vaccination program. Here, we describe a highly attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that can be manufactured at large scale and is protective in a relevant animal model. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. The evolution of brain size is well documented, but the evolution of brain numbers is still missing. This study is the first to reconstruct the evolution of brain numbers across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

The molecular chaperone TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between HSP90 and TRAP1, making their utility as probes of TRAP1-specific function questionable. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This work provides a mechanistic basis for the potential of TRAP1 inhibitors as probes of mitochondrial function in cancer. It also suggests that TRAP1 may be a useful target

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, and their disassembly is critical for many cellular processes. The proteins that disassemble actin filaments are called actin depolymerizing factors (ADF/cofilins). ADF/cofilins are important regulators of cell morphology and migration, and they are involved in diseases such as cancer and Alzheimer’s disease. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilins sever actin filaments is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilins bind to actin filaments and induce a mechanical torque, which enhances severing of highly connected filament networks. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the enhanced severing of filament networks in cells. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical for the efficient disassembly of highly connected filament networks, which are found in cells. Our results also suggest that the mechanical properties of the cytoskeleton can be regulated by ADF/cofilins. This regulation may be important for controlling the dynamics of the cytoskeleton and for the regulation of cellular processes. (Show more)

Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food supply. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island was colonized by different waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not a homogeneous process, and that the genetic structure is also influenced by geography. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. They also have implications for the study of human migration and the role of geography in shaping the genetic structure of human populations. (Less)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which the emotions of others influence our own. We show that this occurs even when people are not directly interacting with the content that is influencing them. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social media platforms.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary conduits for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of mRNA modifications can have a variety of effects on protein synthesis, including changing the rate of translation and the identity of the protein synthesized. Here, we show that the most common mRNA modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest impact on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ can have a significant impact on the translation of mRNAs in cells. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social engagement. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of vertebrates in the water. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a cooler temperature in the nasal cavity, but the molecular basis for this phenomenon has not been elucidated. We show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the temperature found in the nasal cavity than at the temperature of the body core. This temperature-dependent growth is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway, which is activated by the viral RNA genome of rhinovirus.

The use of pesticides in agriculture is increasing worldwide, and the use of insecticides in particular is associated with a risk to aquatic ecosystems. However, the extent of this risk is unknown. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global extent of the risk to aquatic ecosystems from agricultural insecticides. We show that the risk is high, and that it is increasing. Our results highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, and it is possible that animals are a source of continued human infection. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of animals in the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and the need for a more comprehensive approach to the study of the virus. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is not being addressed. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of the dams, and the solutions that are needed. The paper also proposes a new approach to the development of renewable energy that is more sustainable and equitable.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the number of affected individuals is expected to increase dramatically in the coming decades. The disease is characterized by a complex interplay between neurodegeneration and the immune system, but the molecular events that initiate the inflammatory response are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the production of a variety of potent immune factors by neurons. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may be a significant contributor to the disease pathogenesis. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still lacking. Here we present the results of a comprehensive survey of the chicken in the archaeological record. We show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens dates to the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant, and that the species was fully integrated into the local economy by the first century B.C.E. This is a crucial step in the adoption of the chicken in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell. This study shows that the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein, is a complex process with multiple steps. The study also shows that the protein can fold to a native-like intermediate, which is a step on the way to the native state. The intermediate is not the final state, but it is a step that is important for the folding process. The study is important for understanding the role of intermediates in protein folding. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they are thought to function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing this cap is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. We also show that this enzyme, which is normally inactive under these conditions, prefers to remove capped substrates over their counterparts that are tri- or diphosphorylated. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of the enzyme positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study reveals a mechanism for how a single enzyme can have differential impact on the rates at which capped and uncapped 5′ termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation. Such a mechanism could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific therapy to restore immune function after sepsis. We have demonstrated that citrulline, an amino acid that is converted to arginine in the body, is an effective strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a potential strategy to treat other conditions in which arginine levels are low.

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Read more

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of activity at a rate that is proportional to the magnitude of the perturbation. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, avalanches, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be changed by external stimuli. In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed from a semiconductor to a metal by applying strain. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring the properties of diamond and for developing new devices and applications. Our work provides a fundamental understanding of the properties of diamond under strain and has implications for the design of devices and materials in the future.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new strategies for the control of plant fungal diseases. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, NCR peptides, and their application in the control of plant fungal diseases.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm changes substantially after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that this contribution is dependent on the duration of storage. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work also provides a resource for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for hemostasis. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain of VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that the binding is regulated by flow. We also show that the binding is reversible and that the binding state can be switched by force. These findings provide a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to study the impact of viruses on human health. This study is a major step forward in the study of viruses in the human microbiome, and the data presented here will be a valuable resource for the scientific community for years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the instrument to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has changed over time, and the temperature of the surface of the Earth at the time of the origin of life is a key factor in the origin of life. We show that the temperature of the surface of the Earth was higher in the past than it is today, and that this temperature has decreased over time.

Ion channels are the key to the function of the nervous system. In this study, we found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel has a unique form of inactivation that is state-dependent and closed state-dependent. This is the first report of a K+ channel with such a unique form of inactivation.

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the parasite’s surface proteins in this process is unclear. Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed from a semiconductor to a metal by applying strain. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring the properties of diamond and for developing new devices and applications. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. It also provides a rationale for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of low humidity on influenza-associated morbidity and mortality. This article is protected

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes a sentence. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain remain largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation. We also show that the merge operation is necessary for the construction of complex syntactic structures. Our results suggest that the brain represents the structure of a sentence as a tree of nested phrases. This tree is built up word by word, and is compressed into a single representation of the entire sentence. This work provides initial evidence for a neural implementation of the merge operation postulated by linguists. It also provides a new perspective on the nature of the language stream.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in the development of many organs. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which may be used to regulate the two forms of Axin in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and this effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system. Here we show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, the ventral tegmental area, and the locus coeruleus. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for controlling the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis could be used to improve nitrogen use efficiency in agriculture and to develop sustainable nitrogen-fixing biofertilizers. (Show more)

The results suggest that the program may have contributed to sustainable forest management, but the program’s impact on forest outcomes was not statistically significant. Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is the target of the majority of neutralizing antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. We engineered the RBD of the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence to improve its manufacturability and immunogenicity. The engineered RBD was presented on a virus-like particle (VLP) and showed enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor in infants. It is caused by mutations in the kinase anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK). Recently, we identified secreted ALKAL proteins as ligands for ALK. Here, we show that these proteins are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in the development of human and zebrafish iridophores and suggest a role of ALKALs in the development of other neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the time and place of its origin are still debated. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative period of its evolution. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague we know today was already widespread in Eurasia by the end of the Neolithic. This rapid spread is accompanied by a stepwise pattern of gene loss, suggesting that the pathogen was already adapted to its new environment. These data provide a unique view of the formative years of plague, which will be useful for future studies on the origins of this disease. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM was associated with support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also have implications for understanding the relationship between masculinity and political attitudes more generally.

The management of agricultural systems can influence the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. However, the effects of these practices on soil C dynamics are highly uncertain, especially on grassland-derived Mollisols. We show that soil C storage and distribution can be enhanced by a range of management practices in a long-term field experiment. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and rotational grazing of pastures. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester soil C and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We systematically identified and characterized risk factors for spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that can be used to prioritize research and public health interventions to prevent future outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of the nectar is often an important factor in the success of pollination, as it can serve as a visual cue for pollinators. Here, we show that the color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this alkaloid in the plant, and demonstrate that the alkaloid is attractive to a vertebrate pollinator. This work provides evidence for the convergence of this trait in two distantly related plants, and suggests that the red color of the nectar is likely to be a key factor in the success of pollination. This work also highlights the potential for the discovery of new bioactive compounds in the study of plant–animal interactions. (Show more)

We present a case study of the genetic landscape of southern Germany during the Early Medieval period. Our data show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia, and even to southeastern Europe. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Our study also highlights the need for a better understanding of the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe during the Early Medieval period. This is of particular interest in the context of the so-called “migration bottleneck” hypothesis, which suggests that the genetic structure of modern Europeans is the result of a single major wave of migration from outside the continent during the Iron Age.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results show that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5 are opposite to each other. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results also suggest that bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of bat coronaviruses and the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. They also suggest that the use of human cells for pseudovirus entry assays may lead to an overestimation of the cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. These findings are important for understanding the evolution of bat coronaviruses and the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in

We describe the use of a global cloud-based platform, IDseq, to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of undifferentiated febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which was detected in a patient before the national outbreak. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using IDseq to perform unbiased pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study also highlights the need for a global effort to improve the surveillance of emerging pathogens.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. The lagging strand template is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a processive manner, but the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic studies that reveal that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable on undamaged DNA, but rather is stable on the lagging strand template. This behavior is critical for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results have implications for the replication of the human genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA and synthesize a variety of RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a new way to measure the physical appearance of neighborhoods, which is an important metric for urban planning and policy.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is not fully understood. In this study, we found that the patients with severe and critical COVID-19 had high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, was given to the patients, and the results showed that it was effective in reducing mortality. This study provides a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal. The ability to control copper levels in cells is therefore critical for the survival of fungi. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan BGC, which is responsible for the biosynthesis of the siderophore xanthocillin, also functions to control intracellular copper levels in Aspergillus fumigatus. The copper-chelating properties of xan BGC-derived isocyanides are demonstrated in vitro and in vivo, and the ability of xan BGC isocyanides to mediate interactions with competing microbes is shown. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the control of copper levels in fungi and may have implications for the interactions of fungi with other microbes. (Show more)

Silica is a major component of the Martian crust, and its origin and distribution are important to understanding the history of the planet. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is the first evidence for this polymorph on another planet.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is increasing in many regions. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees, and that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to the vulnerability of forests to LSFs. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing risk of frost damage.

Th17 cells are a critical component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells, and that this process requires the transcription factor T-bet. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by motor neuron toxicity. We have developed a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease process and to screen for compounds that alleviate toxicity. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate motor neuron toxicity in ALS. The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the gut microbiota of the vector, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We identify a protein, antifreeze glycoprotein, that is expressed by the vector and is critical for Anaplasma colonization. We show that the protein alters the integrity of the gut barrier and the peritrophic matrix, which are critical obstacles for pathogen colonization. Mechanistically, the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of the microbiota in pathogen colonization of arthropod vectors. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The discovery of a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, Jinguofortis, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian tail.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of its components. In this paper, we show that one of the components, the stratospheric water vapor, has a significant impact on the climate system.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of colors, from red to blue, and even to ultraviolet. However, the biochemical basis of the color of some vertebrates, such as the green color of frogs, is poorly understood. Here, we show that the green color of frogs is due to the presence of a protein that binds biliverdin, a molecule that is normally present in the blood. This discovery is important because it shows that the green color of frogs is not a mere accident, but a functional trait that has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of frogs. Additionally, this study introduces a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a model for the evolution of a color in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the ability of cancer cells to survive in hypoxic conditions is critical to the development of cancer. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is increased in cancer stem cells, and NANOG-positive cells are responsible for tumor initiation. Thus, our study suggests that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for cancer therapy.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. This controversy has been fueled by the use of the Latin term abortivum in many sources, which has led some scholars to suggest that the skin of fetal calves or sheep was used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding the cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and the circadian rhythm. Here, we report the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific deletion of RORα (RORαΔIEC) in mice. We find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in the D614G mutant form and show that this form of the spike is more flexible and open, which may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of the pandemic on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase by nearly 40%, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. (Less)

The chemical properties of atoms are central to chemistry. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. These results are important for understanding the chemistry of matter under pressure and for the development of predictive models. They also have implications for the chemistry of the universe, as pressure is a key parameter in astrophysics. This work is a first step toward the understanding of the chemistry of matter under pressure.

Fire is a key natural process in the global carbon cycle, but its role in climate change is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography can reduce global fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. However, this effect is uncertain and depends on the future trajectory of human demography, socioeconomic development, and climate. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to better understand the role of human demography in future fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a specific symbiont. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the host to maintain a healthy symbiosis. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their symbioses. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data.

The Black Death, which killed millions of people in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The disease originated in Asia, and its arrival in Europe is often attributed to a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague. However, our study shows that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into Europe, which were delayed by 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the bacterium was introduced into Europe via trade routes, and that the disease was able to establish itself in Europe only after a long period of adaptation. This study provides evidence for a more complex picture of the Black Death, and it has implications for our understanding of the spread of other diseases in the past. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. However, they are also a major prey item for a variety of predators, including humans. In recent years, a sea-star wasting disease has been spreading along the Pacific Coast of North America, causing the rapid death of many species. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is highly contagious. This study provides a clear example of the impact of a disease on the functioning of marine ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that an antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is able to efficiently kill AML cells in vitro and in vivo. This antibody is capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, our results suggest that IL1RAP may be a promising target for antibody-based therapy in other diseases where IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of tumor cells. This study provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP in the treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other diseases where IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of tumor cells. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island was colonized by different waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not a homogeneous process, and that the genetic structure is also influenced by geography. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. They also have implications for the study of human migration and the genetic history of Africa and Asia. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. The protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress two other genes. The RNA and protein compete for the same ribosomes, suggesting that the two functions are not mutually exclusive. This is the first report of a protein encoded by an sRNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants.
