Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We propose a method to convert the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting model is robust across different crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how the index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed method can be used to improve the accuracy of crop monitoring systems worldwide.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that is thought to involve the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. Soil respiration is a major carbon flux in the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most difficult to model, because of the complexity of the ecological and physiological changes that occurred at the time. Here, we show that the molecular evolution of plastid genomes is linked to the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We demonstrate that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes that occurred during the transition to parasitism. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This process is likely to have played a key role in the evolution of the plastid genome. View Full-Text

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of chemical energy on Earth. The biosynthesis of the photosynthetic pigments, bacteriochlorophyll and bacteriopheophytin, is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is O2 sensitive, the other O2 dependent. The O2-dependent enzyme is encoded by a gene in cyanobacteria and in some phototrophic bacteria, whereas the O2-sensitive enzyme is encoded by a gene in plants and cyanobacteria. Here, we show that the O2-dependent enzyme in cyanobacteria and in phototrophic bacteria is encoded by a gene in a third group of organisms, the betaproteobacterium Rubrivivax gelatinosus. These data reveal three classes of the enzyme, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is associated with the development of disease and the severity of disease. Neuroinflammation is also associated with the development of disease-modifying therapies. In this study, we identified a key signaling molecule, neuroprotective kinase 1 (ASK1), that is involved in the development of neuroinflammation. We found that ASK1 is involved in the development of neuroinflammation in the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapies for multiple sclerosis and other neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme droughts in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis. The genetic basis of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Our results suggest that the behavioral flexibility of Drosophila is controlled by the activity of Rac1-dependent forgetting. This study provides a framework for understanding the genetic basis of autism. It also provides a model system for studying the molecular mechanisms of behavioral flexibility. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. The results also highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder of unknown cause. Here, we report a patient with Stormorken syndrome, and we show that the underlying cause is gain-of-function mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1, respectively. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome, and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with this disorder.

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread through the brain in a noncell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is associated with the internalization of aggregates. We also show that the internalization of aggregates is required for the spread of disease. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also suggest that targeting the internalization of aggregates may be a potential therapeutic strategy for these diseases. (Show more)

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves and are considered as the natural reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not fully understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated its immunosuppressive function in the host. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting the immunosuppressant protein in bats. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of zoonotic viruses and may help to develop a strategy to prevent future outbreaks. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which is involved in the production of one-carbon units. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma cells. These findings have implications for the treatment of lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including the well-known SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a mechanism for the formation of inclusions in ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)
We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be used to study many-body physics with neutral atoms and to engineer exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants, including the origin of the flowering plants. The earliest flowering plants are poorly known, and the origin of the group is still debated. Here, we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the early Cretaceous of Spain. Our study shows that Montsechia is an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it is the earliest known member of the Ceratophyllum clade. This opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. Parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous human pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 thousand years ago) and show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and this rise is accelerating. These changes are due to a combination of natural and human influences, but the dominant influence is from the industrial era. This study provides a detailed analysis of the acceleration of sea level over the last 25 y, which is the time period for which we have the most precise satellite altimeter data. The results are consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections, but the study also shows that the acceleration is not constant, and that the rate of rise will continue to increase in the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this pattern continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a critical piece of information for understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain, and the structure of the enzyme–transition state complex is even more difficult to obtain. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to obtain the structure of the enzyme–transition state complex, and how this structure can be used to understand the mechanism of an enzyme.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a newly emerged coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a specific symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is at its most vulnerable to predation. These findings suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their symbioses. This article is protected by copyright. This study shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved by teaching teachers to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. This intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools around the world.

Alkylation of DNA is a major source of mutagenesis in both in vitro and in vivo systems. However, the molecular mechanisms of how DNA alkylation affects the fidelity of transcription remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can be bypassed by pol II in a sequence-dependent manner. The transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We determined how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection. We found that the spike protein of MERS-CoV, which is the target of the virus-induced pneumonia, resists conformational changes during cell entry. These conformational changes are required for the second fusion-activating cleavage, which is essential for virus entry into cells. Thus, the first S proteolysis expands virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection. It also provides a rationale for the development of therapeutic strategies to limit the spread of MERS-CoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study provides robust evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can lead to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and that this increase is sustained over time. The study also provides evidence that the effect of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals is not limited to the cafeteria in which the change was made. These findings have important implications for the design of interventions to increase the consumption of plant-based diets and to reduce the environmental and health impacts of food consumption.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we use a quantitative proteomics approach to study the surfaceome of a collection of six oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, and KRAS, in a single cell line. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant contribution to the field of cancer biology.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

SARS-CoV-2 is the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. The protein ORF8 is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the immune system. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 at 2.04-Å resolution. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is likely important for the unique activities of ORF8, including immune suppression and evasion. These activities may be mediated by the unique large-scale assembly of ORF8, which is also specific to SARS-CoV-2. This work provides a molecular understanding of the unique activities of ORF8 and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) and its receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into cortical astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. These results suggest that hypobaric hypoxia may induce cerebral edema via the CRF/CRFR1/AQP4 signaling pathway. This pathway may be a potential target for the development of new therapies for cerebral edema. (Show more)

The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. But what if we have not had complete experience? What if we have only a partial view of the world? What if we have only a partial view of the world because we have not yet collected all the data? This paper addresses these questions. It describes a new way of thinking about the scientific method that is based on the idea that we can learn from experience even when we have only a partial view of the world. It also describes some new statistical methods that are based on this new way of thinking.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of a functional vascular network. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that are required to induce EC development remains unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly induce the development of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the formation of a vascular network. It also provides a potential approach for the treatment of vascular disorders. The discovery of the ligand for the “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of a number of additional RTKs with similar functions. In this study, we show that the augmentor ligands play an important role in the development of the zebrafish iridophore system. We also demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of the eye and the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model for understanding the function of the augmentor ligands in vivo. It also provides a foundation for the development of new strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function, and its deficiency in β-cells causes glucose intolerance due to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. These findings provide a molecular basis for the role of STING in T2D and suggest a potential therapeutic target for T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, based on their genome organization. The group that causes human influenza has a segmented genome, which is packaged into virions by a selective mechanism. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of this group, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and favors the copackaging of interacting RNA segments. Our results provide a molecular understanding of the selective packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. This knowledge will be useful for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including the local hemodynamic environment. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical factor in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a new way to measure the physical appearance of neighborhoods, which is important for understanding the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of data, such as aerial imagery. Our results are available at https://github

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropod pests remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, and demonstrated that this channel is also involved in the avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular basis for the use of natural repellents in pest control, and also highlights the evolutionary conservation of the TRP channel family in arthropod evolution. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host may play an important role. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the time between cell infection and viral production is likely short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Finally, we show that a drug given at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load. These results can help guide the development of effective antiviral strategies for the control of ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the ongoing bleaching event, which is driven by global warming. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis and may help to explain the observed resilience of some coral species. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help to predict the fate of coral reefs in a warming world.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication between the host and the microbiome. In this study, we show that the intestinal tumor model of Drosophila melanogaster leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and a loss of the intestinal barrier. We also show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond well to treatment. In this study, we show that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this up-regulation is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo signaling, and BMI1. We also show that the expression of ROR1 is associated with the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize and re-engrave Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with paclitaxel alone in eradicating PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key event in the history of the climate system, but the exact timing and causes are still debated. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of this event is consistent with the timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our findings highlight the need to improve the management of freshwater fisheries to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical signaling pathways that mediate regeneration in the adult Drosophila and Caenorhabditis elegans nervous systems. This discovery opens up a new avenue for the discovery of genes and pathways that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult mammalian CNS.

Recombination is a fundamental process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we provide a detailed view of recombination activity in a flowering plant.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has revolutionized our understanding of the brain. However, the RSN is a small fraction of total brain activity, and its precise organization is unknown. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant RSN is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network function was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant RSN in cerebral blood flow. In healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest. In contrast, in advanced Parkinson’s disease, the dominant RSN was activated during rest. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of the loss of the dominant RSN in Alzheimer’s disease illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for Parkinson’s disease, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct link between the metabolic organization of the brain and the function of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most prominent modification of mRNA. It is thought to be important for mRNA stability and translation. Here we show that the 5′ cap structure is not the only modification that can be present on mRNA. We find that the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This work also demonstrates that the NAD+ modification is produced in the nucleus and is transported to the mitochondria. Metabolic memory is the ability of the body to maintain a favorable state for the long-term control of blood glucose. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These epigenetic changes are associated with blood glucose levels in the past and may contribute to the maintenance of a favorable metabolic state.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. In this study, we identified a role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the development of the psychological symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds, and the fruit of the closely related species Solanum pennellii are nearly devoid of these compounds. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be useful for improving the flavor of tomato and other fruit species. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most pervasive and profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. Our results highlight the need to consider the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, as they are likely to interact in ways that will have profound implications for the functioning of the biosphere.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial memory. The organization of the MEC is not well understood, in part because of the difficulty of studying the structure of this region in freely behaving animals. Here, we use a portable two-photon microscope to image the structure of the MEC in freely behaving mice. We find that the organization of the MEC is more complex than previously thought.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can function as a flowering signal between plants of the same species. This study illustrates the importance of FTs as a flowering signal in plants and may have implications for understanding the evolution of flowering time in plants.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this study, we show that the speed at which we respond to others can reveal something about our understanding of them.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the electrical impulse. The SAN is a highly organized network of cells that is able to maintain a constant heart rate under normal and pathological conditions. In this study, we show that the activity of the SAN is regulated by a mechanism that links the content of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores with the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane. This mechanism is mediated by stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in cardiomyocytes. Our findings reveal a previously unknown mechanism of regulation of the SAN that may be relevant to the development of new therapies for arrhythmia disorders. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. In this study, we show that Si can enhance the resistance of rice against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, by promoting the accumulation of Si in the plant. This study also reveals a potential mechanism of how Si can promote resistance against insect herbivores. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect plants from insect attack. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still unclear. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings may help to understand the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in human diseases.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that is thought to involve the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This mechanism is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity for storage. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and are the primary source of many pharmaceuticals. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and we show that the size, shape, and geometry of the DNA nanostructures are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can alter the structure and function of nearshore ecosystems. However, the relative importance of the many small tributaries that drain into these lakes is unknown. We show that the majority of the nutrients that fuel coastal algal blooms come from a small number of large tributaries, but that the nutrients from smaller tributaries are more bioavailable and may be more important for fueling algal blooms in the nearshore zone. Our findings highlight the need to consider the role of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication, especially in large lakes, and to develop strategies to manage nutrient inputs from these areas.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a random force, and we show that this behavior is a consequence of the underlying network architecture. Our results suggest that the dynamics of chemical networks in thermodynamic environments may be more complex than previously thought.

This study provides a detailed description of the effects of an antibody against a specific receptor on the brain’s electrical activity. The results are important for understanding the mechanisms of action of this class of antibodies, which are used in the treatment of a variety of neurological disorders. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of antibodies on the brain’s electrical activity. This work is important for the development of new therapies for neurological disorders.

The history of carbon (C) perturbation events throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into how the Earth system responds to abrupt warming. However, most studies focused on short-term warming events that were superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present an integrated proxy (C and uranium [U] isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative C and U isotopic excursions coincident with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 partial pressure and a biodiversity nadir. The isotopic excursions can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over 300 kyr and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxic conditions can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This work provides a new perspective on the history of C perturbation events and the potential for global warming events in the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate commitments to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that most plantations are already deforested by the time certification is granted. Our results suggest that certification is most effective in reducing deforestation in areas that are already deforested, and that certification is not effective in reducing deforestation in peatlands or active fire. These findings highlight the need for certification to be used in combination with other tools to reduce tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a key regulator of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the exocyst component EXO70, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual is often a key determinant of reproductive success. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In others, the sex of an individual is determined by multiple interacting loci, resulting in a spectrum of sex classes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. We find that multiple alleles of a sex determination system can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be used to track the evolution of new alleles. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of sex determination and the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Less)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of free radicals and reactive intermediates. In this study, we show that the levels of iron in the retina can influence the levels of reactive intermediates and the viability of the retina. These findings have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and other retinal diseases. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of community structure, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it leads to the loss of morphological and functional diversity. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the diversification of feeding strategies. Our results help to understand the evolution of specialization in predators, and the role of morphological innovation in the diversification of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly evolved structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution, and the fossil record is sparse between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which is involved in the production of one-carbon units. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma cells, which may be exploited in the development of new therapies. This work is a step toward the development of a metabolic approach to cancer therapy.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the loss of natural landscapes is thought to be a major contributor to the global nutrition crisis. However, the impact of deforestation on people’s diets has not been well studied. We show that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 200% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
